p: Insecticide-treated materials (ITMs) deployed as bednets are highly effective in preventing transmission of malaria [ 7] and other nocturnally transmitted vector-borne diseases including Chagas disease [ 8], leishmaniasis [ 9], and lymphatic filariasis [ 10]. Control of dengue diurnal vectors using ITMs has similarly been demonstrated, mainly as insecticide treated curtains (ITCs) [ 11– 16]. The residual formulations of insecticides used on ITCs allow for a potentially long-lasting effect, and ITCs are ‘user-friendly’, requiring little additional work or behavioral change by householders. They are also well accepted by communities [ 17], because their perceived efficacy is reinforced by the reduction in other biting insects, cockroaches, houseflies and other insect pests [ 11].
